证据片段: The uniform white oxide layer, once formed, can grow in thickness without any visible changes up to a thickness of 60 to $8 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

证据片段: The rods shown in Fig. 4 originated from five different lots of cladding, all with the same nominal annealing parameter and with only small differences in chemical composition

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk3
证据片段: The oxide film observed on metallographic cross sections with light microscopy up to magnifications of $5 0 0 \times$ appears uniform up to thicknesses of 60 to $7 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk4
证据片段: Oxide thickness measurements were made in hot cells on metallographic cross sections of a number of different fuel rods.

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk4
证据片段: The oxide thickness measurements obtained by metallography were used to verify the oxide thickness measurements made at poolside with the eddy current (E.C.) probe.

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk4
证据片段: Figure 10 indicates that good agreement was obtained between the poolside and hot cell measurements.

证据片段: The thickness of the oxide layer, $X _ { \mathrm { t r a n } }$ , at the transition point $\mathbf { \tau } ( \mathbf { m } )$ is given by the equation $X _ { \mathrm { t r a n } } = 7 . 7 4 9 \cdot 1 0 ^ { - 6 } \exp \left( - 7 9 0 / T \right)$

证据片段: the thermal conductivity of Zircaloy oxide is taken to be $1 . 7 3 \ \mathrm { W / m / K }$

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk5
证据片段: the MATPRO corrosion model has a correct temperature dependence

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk5
证据片段: the corrosion performance of Zircaloy-4 cladding is improved by longer and/ or higher temperature anneals in the alpha range after the material has been beta quenched

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
证据片段: The in-reactor corrosion susceptibility of Zircaloy-4 fuel rod cladding is dependent on the thermo-mechanical treatment received by the cladding after beta quenching. Longer annealing times and higher annealing temperatures in the alpha range lead in general to better corrosion performance.
工艺步骤: thermo-mechanical treatment after beta quenching; annealing in alpha range

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
证据片段: The visual appearance of Zircaloy-4 clad PWR fuel rods changes from a uniform black oxide layer to a mottled black-and-white oxide between 10 and 15 μm thickness.

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
证据片段: The oxide layer formed on Zircaloy-4 PWR fuel rods may start delaminating at a thickness of 60 to 80 μm and part of the oxide may spall off.

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
证据片段: The corrosion parameter, incorporated in a modified MATPRO corrosion model, provides a measure of the corrosion susceptibility of Zircaloy-4 cladding of a given chemical composition and produced by a given thermo-mechanical treatment.

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
证据片段: The corrosion parameter shows good correlation with the second-order cumulative annealing parameter (SOCAP) defined by Gros and Wadier [5]. This parameter is related to the size of intermetallic precipitates in Zircaloy-4.

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
证据片段: The minima in oxide thickness at spacer grid positions and at positions downstream from the grids are due to lower cladding surface temperatures resulting from more turbulent coolant flow within the grids and at the exit of the grids.

文献ID: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
证据片段: With sufficient detail in the thermal-hydraulics calculations and an accurate calculation of the metal-oxide interface temperature at every point along the fuel rod, it is in principle possible to predict the whole oxide profile with only a single corrosion parameter.
